title: Exclusive: OpenAI Used Kenyan Workers on Less Than $2 Per Hour to Make ChatGPT Less Toxic

last_post.content:
Anyway I brought this up at the LLM discussion group at an academic conference this week:

https://time.com/6247678/openai-chatgpt-kenya-workers/

(tl;dr—Kenyan workers are being paid exploitative-level wages to manually filter out the worst stuff from the internet and this is necessary for how LLM's work)

And in that hour, only one person even addressed the issue, and their take was ~ "colonial exploitation is good, actually" and everyone just sorta nodded their heads

title: AI Written, AI Read cartoon - Marketoonist | Tom Fishburne

last_post.content:
"AI Written, AI Read" https://marketoonist.com/2023/03/ai-written-ai-read.html

Automated expansion of text is often used together with automated summarization of text.

Maybe we should just write short words directly, so that the whole "AI" could be avoided (almost) completely for regular communication needs.

The #Fediverse has a business model problem. (Use the term "business" loosely if you like.)

Today's exhibit: Guppe groups is a loss-making project, donations are insufficient, and the developers will need to shut it down if that doesn't change asap. Given all the things they tried already, that seems unlikely.

Lots of projects will end up like this if we don't solve this.

https://web.immers.space/2023/05/farewell-to-guppe/

title: Moderator Mayhem: A Mobile Game To See How Well YOU Can Handle Content Moderation

last_post.content:
Okay folks: this morning we're launching something we think is pretty useful. Lots of people have strong opinions on how content moderation should work, but they've never done it. So we built a content moderation mobile game (browser-based): https://moderatormayhem.engine.is/

Details about it are here: https://www.techdirt.com/2023/05/11/moderator-mayhem-a-mobile-game-to-see-how-well-you-can-handle-content-moderation/
Join me at posit::conf(2023) to learn more about tidy time series and forecasting in R. https://youtu.be/g4221KXM7hU Register now at http://pos.it/conf to secure your spot. #positconf2023

The House of Commons has released a thoughtful, critical report on UK research quality

The recommendations to government are excellent, both practical and progressive

Highlights:

Make all research open access

Require data and code accompany all publications

Move peer-review and publication acceptance before data collection

Specifically fund replications

Remove “originality” from REF, instead require transparency

Impose a 3-year minimum term for all postdocs

https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm5803/cmselect/cmsctech/101/summary.html

@matthieu_xyz @liaizon@social.wake.st yes! That's in the works too. We brought on board the gentleman who created https://wordpress.org/plugins/activitypub/ to bring ActivityPub support to WordPress sites.

He's working now on integrating it for all WordPress.com sites and making it a better experience.

Right now, it isn't feature-complete enough for me, personally, to say it's ready for folks who aren't early adopters and okay with rough edges.

The sharing and auto-posting is a bit easier to do since there is the existing model of doing it on legacy social media platforms.

On the Tumblr side of the company, same thing. Want to get it to be ActivityPub-compliant. I don't work over there but I imagine that's a pretty big effort and I don't know where it stands off hand.

Long answer but yes. Having a site published using the ActivityPub protocol is on the horizon.

title: Andreessen Horowitz's State of Crypto report: Narrative over numbers

last_post.content:
A deep dive on Andreessen Horowitz's latest "State of Crypto" report. In short: they want people to keep buying crypto, and are not above publishing blatant falsehoods to convince them to do so.

The report itself is 60 pages long, so this is a long one.

https://newsletter.mollywhite.net/p/andreessen-horowitzs-state-of-crypto

I ❤ #Calckey - I migrated both my Mastodon accounts here, but can't import the second one's posts at the moment, that's okay tho; nothing I can't post again! 😊

I know you all love Fediverse analytics, so here's a peek under the hood at https://calckey.social.

In the first chart, we see active users on https://calckey.social. The red means reading, and the yellow mean writing. For a server of about 1,650, 1/3 are active on a daily basis.

The next chart shows Fediverse requests. That measures how much demand there is for stuff on https://calckey.social.

All of this has resulted in growing pains, but so far, we've risen to the occasion.

It also helps that we have a passionate community of people who are welcoming and help others as needed ♥

Glad this server is leading the way with #Calckey!

There it is: #ARD, the biggest public broadcaster in the world, opened its own instance for #Mastodon today – https://ard.social
Its flagship news programme gets the first account: @tagesschau@ard.social.

On #Twitter the #Tagesschau has 4 million Followers, I am curious, how much it gets here and how fast. Could give us a hint on how active the german community on #Mastodon still is. The inoffical @tagesschau@squeet.me had amassed 53k Followers, the other public broadcaster @ZDF 13k in three weeks.

(🧵 1/4)

title: Deskilling on the Job | danah boyd | apophenia

last_post.content:
This blog post on AI's effects on work skills by danah boyd is great.

I learned the concept of "moral crumple zones", introduced by Madeleine Elish. When an autonomous system, such as self-driving car, loses control, it assigns the control back to a human operator. It's too late for the human to do anything, but they will bear the moral and legal responsibility.

The human is the part of the self-driving car that is designated to absorb the moral impact on crash.

http://www.zephoria.org/thoughts/archives/2023/04/21/deskilling-on-the-job.html

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

For 2yrs I've been asking:

-- Why are Charles Babbage's 19th c. contributions to computing delinked from his influential theories of worker control?
-- How do we understand these as two parts of one project?
-- And, what does plantation slavery & British abolition have to do with it?

Forthcoming article!! 👇👇 👇

In the incredible inaugural issue of the new incarnation of Logic(s) 🔥 https://store.logicmag.io/products/issue-19-supa-dupa-skies

title: ​​The 'Past Exonerative Tense' In Stories About Police Killings, Traffic Violence

last_post.content:
"Officer-involved shooting" is a euphemism for "officer shot someone" -- and it's used, by police and journalist, to make reality fuzzy.

If all journalism organizations agreed to, as this commentary advises, abolish the "Exonerative Tense” in headlines (and I'd add, articles as well), journalism would be much improved.

https://www.buzzfeed.com/emersonmalone/police-traffic-safety-headline-language-exoneration

title: Humans and algorithms work together — so study them together

last_post.content:
The US Supreme Court will soon decide if YouTube should be held responsible for allegedly permitting the platform’s recommender algorithms to promote content that radicalized terrorists who killed Nohemi Gonzalez.

Whatever the court concludes, the case highlights an urgent question: how can we govern adaptive algorithms that continually change in response to people’s behavior? The problem? Scientists can't currently answer this question.

See my new article in @nature

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-01521-z

Research Protocol 2021/427 approved by #ANU Human Research Ethics Committee

title: The Intelligence Illusion: a practical guide to the business risks of Generative AI

last_post.content:
Your reminder that I've written a book on the business risks of generative AI. "The Intelligence Illusion"

https://illusion.baldurbjarnason.com/

Stuff I cover (not exhaustive):

- AGI is not happening any time soon.
- AGI and anthropomorphism will cripple your ability to think clearly about AI
- The AI industry has a long history of snake oil and fraud
- These models copy more than you think
- Hallucinations are still a thing and aren't going away.
- AI "reasoning" is quite broken
- Security is a shit show

Also worth mentioning that @jerry@infosec.exchange, admin from infosec.exchange, is also running a #Calckey server.

You can visit it at https://infosec.town

@tyler #Calckey is a fork of #Misskey. One feature of Misskey is the ability to show ads.

Unlike Misskey, Calckey gives you the ability to opt out of ads if you don't like them.

By the way, I don't know of any Calckey servers that show ads right now.

title: Google wants to take over the web

last_post.content:
Google’s vision for the future of search shows how generative AI is all about increasing corporate power.

Instead of sending you to different websites, Google has scraped the open web to generate plagiarized answers to keep you looking at ads on Google. We need to stop being distracted by AI hype and fantasies about intelligent machines, so we can push back on the real threats before it’s too late.

https://www.disconnect.blog/p/google-wants-to-take-over-the-web

#google #tech #search #ai #chatbot #googleio

title: Grace Murray Hopper (1906-1992): A legacy of innovation and service

last_post.content:
Born in 1906, computer scientist Grace Hopper invented the first compiler for computer programming language & was among the first programmers of the Harvard Mk1 computer.

Hopper popularized the idea of machine-independent programming languages & paved the way to develop COBOL (an early high-level programming language). She originated the term "bug" to describe computer glitches & became a celebrated Rear Admiral in the US Navy.
https://news.yale.edu/2017/02/10/grace-murray-hopper-1906-1992-legacy-innovation-and-service #HistoryRemix #science #history
